analyzeResult.content:
PHILIP MORRIS U.S.A.
INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 120 PARK AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017 :selected:
TO: Distribution FROM: Herb Foster
DATE: December 12, 1988
SUBJECT: Virginia Slims Meeting, Dec. 19
On Monday, December 19, a luncheon meeting will be held in conference room 5C to review Virginia Slims advertising.
Over the past few months, there has been considerable debate about the V.S. creative. On the 19th, we want to get the key players together and provide a forum for open discussion. It is important for the continued success of the brand that we have a consensus on future creative direction and that Burnett clearly understands our objectives.
Attending for Burnett will be: Mara Fizdale, Jim Oates, Pete Volz, Martin Dawson, Barbara Stoldt and Johnson Schaff. Historical advertising will be posted, along with approved ads for the first six months, 1989.
While not all-inclusive or intended to guide discussion, here are some of the issues that have been raised:
- Why does the ethnic advertising seem "hotter" than mainline? Is it the styling? Iman? Art direction/attitude?
- Are the oldtimes restricting our ability to do contemporary layouts? Do we need to run oldtimes in every mainline ad? How large do they need to be? Can they have a less prominent role?
- Is our styling for mainline too conservative? Are we running too much "every day" clothes and not enough hot fashion? What should our mix be between elegant/evening wear and casual clothes?
- What roles do specials play? How many specials should we run a year? Do we want traditional specials? (Rosemary for President/Stubby) or real "interrupters" (Raja) ?
- Is the new "ethnic style" layouts in mainline better than the more traditional look? In using big headlines, have we downplayed the "You've come a long way, baby" theme? How far can we go before the advertising begins to look cheap? Do colored brand names work? Are we varying our layout too much?
2044198287

paragraphs.content: INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 120 PARK AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
On Monday, December 19, a luncheon meeting will be held in conference room 5C to review Virginia Slims advertising.

Over the past few months, there has been considerable debate about the V.S. creative. On the 19th, we want to get the key players together and provide a forum for open discussion. It is important for the continued success of the brand that we have a consensus on future creative direction and that Burnett clearly understands our objectives.

Attending for Burnett will be: Mara Fizdale, Jim Oates, Pete Volz, Martin Dawson, Barbara Stoldt and Johnson Schaff. Historical advertising will be posted, along with approved ads for the first six months, 1989.
While not all-inclusive or intended to guide discussion, here are some of the issues that have been raised:
- Why does the ethnic advertising seem "hotter" than mainline? Is it the styling? Iman? Art direction/attitude?
- Are the oldtimes restricting our ability to do contemporary layouts? Do we need to run oldtimes in every mainline ad? How large do they need to be? Can they have a less prominent role?
- Is our styling for mainline too conservative? Are we running too much "every day" clothes and not enough hot fashion? What should our mix be between elegant/evening wear and casual clothes?
- What roles do specials play? How many specials should we run a year? Do we want traditional specials? (Rosemary for President/Stubby) or real "interrupters" (Raja) ?

- Is the new "ethnic style" layouts in mainline better than the more traditional look? In using big headlines, have we downplayed the "You've come a long way, baby" theme? How far can we go before the advertising begins to look cheap? Do colored brand names work? Are we varying our layout too much?
